Award.AbstractNarration:
The 17th Meeting of New Researchers in Statistics and Probability, a conference series sponsored by the Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS), is organized by and held for junior researchers. The primary objective is to provide a much needed venue for interaction among new researchers. The meeting will take place over three days, August 6-8, 2015, at the University of Washington, in Seattle, WA. The meeting will be held immediately preceding the Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM) in downtown Seattle. Participants will be statisticians and probabilists who have received their Ph.D. within the past five years or are expecting to receive their degree within the same year. Each participant will present a talk or poster. Topics will cover a variety of areas in statistics and probability, from theory and methods to applications. Senior speakers will give plenary talks for inspiration and other senior researchers will take part in discussion panels covering topics of importance for young people embarking on an academic/research career, such as teaching, mentoring, publishing and funding.

This conference series is explicitly aimed at training the future leaders and workers in statistics and probability. In helping to create networks of new researchers, it lays the groundwork for future collaboration and the informal exchange of ideas and knowledge. It is also critical for professional cohesion, which is particularly important as research fields become more and more specialized. Meeting people outside of one's research specialty area, and learning about their research, favors a more comprehensive view of research, which is important when taking editor positions and other professional service activities. The conference also attracts participants with different backgrounds and nationalities, and underrepresented groups --- women, minorities and people with disabilities --- are explicitly encouraged to attend.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funding from NSF supported the 17th Meeting of New Researchers in Probability and Statistics (NRC), held on the campus of University of Washington in Seattle from August 6-8, 2015.

The NRC meeting is an annual conference organized under the auspices of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS) and aims to promote interaction and networking among new researchers in probability and statistics.

The 17th NRC meeting was attended by 55 participants selected by the Organizing Committee among 85 submitted applicants. Ali Shojaie and Noah Simon from the Department of Biostatistics at the University of Washington chaired the Organizing Committee, which included 5 additional members from IMS-member institutions in US and Europe.

The meeting featured poster presentations by new researchers following short expository talks. In addition to presentations by new researchers, the meeting included plenary talks by senior researchers in probability and statistics, as well as four panels on teaching and mentoring, publication and funding, leadership and data science. Importantly, the conference provided ample opportunities for networking and scientific interaction within junior researchers and between junior and senior researchers. These opportunities are expected to foster collaborations and cross-talk among researchers in various areas.

Additional information about attendants and panels are provided below.

Attendees

55 participants were selected from 85 applicants based on review of applications by the Organizing Committee. Given the goals of the NRC, selected participants were primarily (~90%) junior faculty, or were scheduled to start a faculty position in fall 2015. The 85 applicants came from 61 different institutions, and 68 were domestic (US) applicants. Of domestic applicants, 24 (35%) come from the northeast, 23 (34%) come from the south, 14 (21%) come from the midwest, and 7 (10%) come from the west.

The following senior faculty will present plenary talks or participate at one of discussion panels:

  • Patrick Heagerty (University of Washington)

  • Adrian Raftery (University of Washington)
  • Han Liu (Princeton University -- Tweedie Award winner)
